The impact of a Fourier transform \\( F(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-i\\omega t} z(t) dt \\) on z(t) is considered.

If \\( F(z) \\) is applied to \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0, and then \\( z(t) \\) is allowed to evolve under \\( Lz \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z(t) \\) was evolved under \\( Lz \\) from t = 0 to t = T without applying \\( F(z) \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform \\( F(z) \\) alters the frequency components of \\( z(t) \\), changing the initial state by focusing on specific frequencies. When evolved subsequently under \\( Lz \\), the transformed \\( z(t) \\) will not evolve in the same way as the original would have, displaying different behavior at time T due to modified initial conditions.
